importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the news of Daniel Naroditsky's death was released to the public.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2007 to 2025 captures Naroditsky's career journey, including his early championship wins, rise to grandmaster status, and continued public engagement through streaming and commentary until his death in 2025.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, a prominent American chess grandmaster and educator, passed away at the age of 29 in 2025.
Naroditsky was born in San Mateo County, California, to Jewish immigrant parents from Ukraine and Azerbaijan.
He won the Under 12 world championship in 2007 and became a grandmaster at age 18, establishing himself as a top-tier player in both traditional and blitz chess.
Naroditsky was known for his educational livestreams on platforms like YouTube and Twitch, significantly expanding the visibility and accessibility of chess to a global audience.
He maintained a top-25 ranking in blitz chess and won the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025.
He studied history at Stanford University and later coached junior chess players in Charlotte, North Carolina.
The Charlotte Chess Center announced his death and called him a 'talented chess player, educator, and beloved member of the chess community'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a celebrated American chess grandmaster born in San Mateo County, California, died at the age of 29 in 2025. A child prodigy who won the Under 12 world championship in 2007, he became a grandmaster at 18 and later rose to a top-25 global ranking in blitz chess, winning the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025. Known for his educational livestreams on platforms like YouTube and Twitch, Naroditsky helped introduce chess to millions of people worldwide. He studied history at Stanford University and coached junior players at the Charlotte Chess Center in North Carolina, where he was a beloved figure. Fellow grandmasters, including Hikaru Nakamura and Benjamin Bok, praised his passion, educational approach, and personal connections, expressing shock and grief at his passing. The cause of death is not yet known.
title: Daniel Naroditsky, American Chess Grandmaster and Educator, Dies at 29
